intro: Launaea secunda, commonly known as the desert mallow, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of Africa and the Middle East. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, succulent stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in clusters during the rainy season. Launaea secunda is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments through its deep root system and water-storing tissues. It is often used in traditional medicine and for soil stabilization in degraded landscapes.
